Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailHe says this service – which includes precautions like leaving beer on the doorstep and taking payments over the phone – is a “better model” for the pub at the moment. “Until the coronavirus goes away, I can’t see that changing,” Coomes adds. Meanwhile in Suffolk, The Nutshell, another tiny pub, is hoping to be get permission to sell drinks to people standing outside. Until then, one of the landlords tells The Independent it is ”not really feasible” for his establishment – with an inside space of 15ft by 7ft – to reopen, even with the relaxed rules in early July. “We wouldn’t be able to serve a pint on the bar very easily,” Geoff Page from the Bury St Edmunds pub explains.“The member of staff would have to step back from the bar for the customer to get up from the seat on the edge of the pub to collect the pint.”He estimates the pub would be able to fit five single people inside – all sitting on their on their own – under the social distancing rules, which say people must stay at least one metre apart as a preventative measure against Covid-19. “Our unique selling point – the size of us – happens to be the Achilles heel in this particular situation,” Page says. Martin says they have been told they can serve people outside between 10am to 5pm. “Which is great,” she tells The Independent,” but that’s not when I have any business. I have business in the evening.” Outdoor space has been key for The Rake, a small pub in central London, to plan its reopening on 4 July. The establishment in Borough Market has been open as an off-licence throughout lockdown, with people queueing up in their gardens for takeaway beer – with draught beer poured into an open can, then sealed using a machine on the bar, as an option. When will pubs, cinemas, restaurants and hairdressers be open from?Pubs to offer al fresco dining and takeaway pints under new billOne of Britain’s smallest pubs on reopening during coronavirus“Our small garden is going to be used for customers,” manager George Aldridge tells The Independent. ”We are going to be introducing table service and table bookings – which we have never done before.” Mike Hill, the founder of Utobeer which runs the London pub, tells The Independent: “I think if we didn’t have outside space, and somebody told us we couldn’t use outside space, I would probably seriously consider not opening.”The small size of the pub means customers will not be allowed to drink inside, he adds. While some pubs will be planning to welcome back people in a socially-distanced environment on 4 July, others – including smaller ones – have decided to wait a bit longer. Coomes from Platform 3 in Claygate says his tiny pub – which can fit just one person inside – cannot afford the extra costs that would come with reopening during the pandemic, such as having a person manning the toilets. “I can’t justify having someone do that in my micropub,” he says. ”The figures don’t add up for us.”Speaking about pubs being able to reopen on new conditions, the landlord of The Nutshell – which is thought to be one of the smallest pubs in the UK – tells The Independent: “It is not going to change really very much at all for ourselves at all.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: weston super mare beach people stuck mudflats sea
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Weston Coastguard Rescue Team said it was called out 55 times on WednesdayDozens of beachgoers have been spotted getting stuck in mud flats trying to reach the sea in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset.One onlooker said “over a hundred” people had made their way to the water during low tide but got into difficulty in the soft surface.Pictures from the scene show one woman struggling through the sludge attempting to carry a small child back to the shore.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMembers of the coastguard can be seen attempting to help revellers who had attempted to go for a swim on the hottest day of the year so far.Weston Coastguard Rescue Team said in a tweet it had received 55 call outs on Wednesday, some of which dealt with those stuck in the mud.Lockdown-busting crowds pack beaches and parksThe rescue team has been called out to deal with people struggling on the mudflats at least 12 times in the past month.It has previously warned those heading to the beach to remain vigilant.“Our key safety messages at the moment are that if people travel to the coast to enjoy the hot weather they should check tide times, weather forecasts and local safety signage,” a spokesperson said last month.“People should keep a close eye on their family and ensure they stay safe.“Inflatables should only be used in safe areas such as Marine Lake and not in the sea.”Thousands of Britons have been flocking to beaches and beauty spots across the UK to make the most of the ongoing heatwave.The mercury hit 32.6C (90.6F) on Wednesday near London in the hottest day of 2020 so far, although forecasters say that record could be broken by the end of the week.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Premium.David Frost stamps on idea that&nbspUK could have ability to break free from EU rules – in return for tariff punishment if it takes that pathA proposal seen as the best chance of avoiding a disastrous no-deal Brexit at the end of the year has been rejected by the UK’s chief negotiator.With the talks deadlocked, it was thought the EU could agree to give the UK the ability to break free from its rules – in return for the right to impose tariffs if it chose to do so.The arrangement would have avoided the feared cliff-edge on 31 December, when the UK will crash out of the single market and customs union unless an agreement is struck.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut, in a series of tweets, David Frost, Boris Johnson’s negotiator, announced: “I want to be clear that the government will not agree to ideas like the one currently circulating giving the EU a new right to retaliate with tariffs if we chose to make laws suiting our interests.“We could not leave ourselves open to such unforeseeable economic risk.”Minister won’t comment on chlorinated chicken, claiming US listeningBritish officials had suggested Boris Johnson would consider the compromise, under which the UK would secure the right to deviate from Brussels’ standards in areas such as state aid.The EU was thought to be sceptical – preferring to strike a firm deal, rather than set a path for future conflict in the relationship – but had welcomed what it viewed as new-found flexibility in London.After clashes following recent remote negotiations, optimism had crept up that an agreement could be reached when face-to-face talks resume next week.But, without the proposed fudge – kicking key decisions into the future – the two sides remain at odds over access to UK fishing waters and title: schools england return coronavirus classrooms rules guidelines summer
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Secondary and primary school children&nbspare emerging from lockdown and back into classrooms. Here are some of the measures that schools are implementing to make the transition easier for pupils, staff and parentsIn association with the UK GovernmentHinchingbrooke School is an academy school in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, with more than 1,900 pupils and 200 staff. Teachers started welcoming back A-level students last week.“We’ve only had the Year 12s in so far, but for them it was really clear they were delighted to be back,” says Mark Patterson, school principal, pictured above. “You could see it on their faces. It’s getting back to some sense of routine, structure and normality.He continues: “I think a lot of them have been surprised by how much they’ve missed school. I think if you’d asked them before lockdown ‘Would you like a week off?’, they’d have said ‘Please!’. I bet if you asked them now, they’d say ‘Can I come back?’. I think the parents and students now realise how important school is.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPrior to the return, teachers organised a virtual assembly for Year 10 and 12 pupils, and sent a booklet home detailing the new guidelines which would be in place.5 back-to-school tips for parents&nbsp“Don't give them a lot of small instructions – recognise your child would have had an enormous amount of&nbspinstructions during the course of the day.”“If you are rewarding your child's behaviour, it's very important to do it every time.”“For a child who's been finding it tough,&nbsptalking to another child who's been in the same situation is by far the best way of letting it out.”“It's important to encourage a child to work for themselves and get on with their own inner task.”New measures include red circles marked on the ground that are two metres apart and one-way systems throughout the school.“We’ve reorganised all the classrooms that we’re using so the desks and chairs are two metres apart,” Patterson explains. “We’ve got designated areas set aside at break and lunchtime for each group to go to, and we’ve got signage around the school reminding everybody of the importance of hygiene, frequent hand washing and keeping their distance.”Implementing new measuresRheeya Makwana is one of the Year 12 students who has returned to Hinchingbrooke. “We’ve been having online lessons and voiceover PowerPoints, but it’s not really the same as being in a classroom,” she says. “The structure was really good and I felt like I learned a lot more being back at school. I came home in such a good mood.”Rheeya’s father Yogesh Makwana did have some initial worries about his daughter returning to school: “There’s always some concern, but all the communication from school has been excellent in the build up to it and all the measures that have been put in place have reassured us. If you offered our 13-year-old the chance to go back to school tomorrow, he’d do it in a heartbeat. He misses his classes the social interaction. He loves PE and he does so much at school that he misses.Year 10 pupils Vahine and Lucia will also be returning to the school this week. “The twins are really looking forward to it,” says their mother, Alesia Dickinson. “They’ve been messaging all their friends to find out what group they’re in. Less than a week after we said yes to going back we found out what bubbles they were in and we had clear guidelines about times, rooms and what they can expect when they go back to school. They’re raring to go.”Both Makwana and Dickinson agree that their children have missed the structure of school lessons and that the transition back to the classroom has been easier than expected. “I think it’s a positive thing,” says Dickinson. “I think it’s a step in the right direction. We need to let the children start that process.”Going back to Embark schoolsTrust leader at Embark Matthew Crawford, pictured below, has been welcoming back primary pupils to the Federation’s schools across Derbyshire.“The feedback we have had so far from all the schools across the Trust is that it’s going really well in terms of welcoming the children back,” he says. “It’s not a one-size-fits-all. Each school has done a risk assessment based on what they can do.”Most Embark schools are now back at around 25-30 per cent capacity, Crawford says. It's up from around two per cent when lockdown began, when it was just key workers’ children and more vulnerable pupils in the classroom.“It’s lovely to hear the children playing and see schools becoming vibrant again,” he adds. “As soon as lockdown began, we started work on our Reconnection to Recovery and Resilience programme, a nine-stage support package to welcome children back safely.”Keyworker Vicki Ellis has two children who have returned to one of Embark's schools Richardson Endowed Primary - Amelia in Year 3 and Darcey in Year 1, pictured below.The first day the girls were back I was wondering how they were all day. I knew the school had done everything possible to welcome the children back in a happy, positive way but I worried whether Amelia and Darcey were enjoying themselves. But when they came home they were so happy to have had that day at school – and eager to go back next day. Crawford explains that the school has tried to make the transition back to the classroom as fun as possible for the children: “We’re following the guidelines but in a way that’s fun for the children. We aren’t marking big Xs on the floor. Some of our schools, for example, are painting snakes in bright colours to show the way.”Embark has also shared its programme with schools as far as Devon, Durham, South Gloucestershire and Wales.“It’s a suite of resources and activities that schools can adapt to their own settings, taking the bits that work for them,” explains Crawford. “It’s lovely that the brilliant work of our staff is making a difference and impacting the lives of millions of children across the country, not just the 3,000 within our Trust.”Information in this article applies to schools in England only. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.And which countries are yet to even reach the peak?The Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Coronavirus lockdowns are lifting around the world, raising concerns that it could trigger a new wave of infections.Some countries that experienced a significant drop in new Covid-19 cases in April and May are now beginning to experience an uptick in confirmed daily cases.The concerning trend can be seen in several countries throughout the Middle East, most notably in Iran where new cases briefly dropped below 1,000 in early May but have now more than doubled.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIran was one of the first countries to experience a significant outbreak of the deadly virus, with close to 200,000 total cases recorded.Looking at a smoothed seven-day rolling average for new daily cases, Iran's second wave came almost exactly one month after the first wave.The data suggests that Iran may have already reached the peak of its second wave and is now on the decline.Other countries in the region appear to be experiencing a more gradual second wave, with official figures from Israel revealing that new coronavirus cases have been rising consistently for the past three weeks.Israel's second wave remains a long way off the peak of the first wave, and the country remains one of the least affected in the Middle East.In Saudi Arabia, new cases are rising at record rates despite briefly appearing to peak in late May.The false peak means the latest surge of new cases could be counted as a continuation of the first wave, rather than a new second wave.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailTurkey is second only to Iran in terms of total coronavirus cases in the Middle East, and is also beginning to show early signs of a second wave of infections.Recent online search trends in the United States have hinted that a second wave may be on its way, however there is yet to be a sustained drop in new cases since a massive increase in March and April.With more than 2.1 million confirmed cases, the US is by far the worst affected country in the world and has not dropped below 20,000 new daily cases since 1 April.The United Kingdom was briefly the second worst hit country globally but has seen a consistent fall in new cases throughout May and June.With more than 1,000 new confirmed cases each day it continues to be the worst affected country in Europe.Most worryingly of all are the countries that continue to see the number of new cases climb each day.India has seen the number of new cases of Covid-19 rise nearly every day since the virus first came to the country in March, with more than 10,000 cases now recorded each day.A similar situation can be seen in Mexico, where the peak of the first wave appears to not yet have been reached.A new outbreak also appears to be taking hold in Beijing, though official figures from the Chinese capital suggest that it is still relatively small. title: putin russia vote constitutional reform leader 2036
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The vote is deliberately being held in the grey zone,’ says one opposition activistThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Voting has begun across Russia on proposed constitutional reforms that would allow Vladimir Putin to rule until at least 2036.The vote is being brought to Russians via impromptu polling booths on park benches, on buses, in the boots of cars, in theatres and factories, and even in “hot zones” of Covid-19 hospitals. Voting will continue for an unprecedented seven days, and every day will see a lottery draw, raffling anything from supermarket vouchers to cars and apartments. Authorities insist that such creativity is a necessary response to the challenges posed in the era of the coronavirus. Opponents say the extraordinary measures to increase turnout demonstrate the unpopularity of Mr Putin’s decision to prioritise a power grab during a pandemic. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe vote, which was originally planned for 22 April before being rescheduled to this week, will ask Russians for a yes or no answer on over 200 new amendments to the country’s constitution.The most important of these proposed changes – the resetting of presidential term limits – has been routinely under-emphasised in voting literature, and in one case was even omitted. Official messages have concentrated instead on populist measures such as cementing marriage as a union of man and woman, emphasising the role of God, and guaranteeing indexation of pensions and other social payments. The vote is not a referendum per se the amendments have, in fact, already been passed by both parliaments. Pro-democracy groups say that the unclear classification of the vote is no accident. In a referendum, both sides are officially allowed to agitate for and against, and are entitled to airtime and finance. Not so in this campaign.  “The vote was specially set up to avoid any debate,” says Grigory Melkonyants, co-chairman of the independent Golos election monitoring group. “The government can de facto agitate for a yes vote with their campaign literature, but activists campaigning for a no vote are being arrested as we speak.” There have been several early reports of manipulations. Some of the claims related to age-old techniques: for example, evidence of forced voting at large enterprises, where vulnerable, low-paid workers are asked to vote under management supervision. But there were examples of newer tricks too. Earlier this month, a reporter at the liberal Dozhd television network exposed a fraudulent scheme that registered the details of pensioners on electronic voting websites, with the aim of then voting on their behalf. The reporter was summoned by state investigators for his trouble. In the early hours of Thursday morning, another reporter for the same channel managed to vote twice — electronically and in person. That reporter would be fined 30,000 roubles (£350), election authorities confirmed. No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe wide array of voting methods being employed during the week-long vote will make assessing its fairness difficult. Not only is electronic voting possible in two cities – Moscow and Niznny Novgorod – but mobile voting at home and at work is being allowed without extenuating circumstances for the first time. There will be limited scope for independent oversight monitors will only be permitted from regional isions of the Public Chamber, a quasi-governmental organisation. “The vote is deliberately being held in the grey zone,” says Mr Melkonyants. “Those who want to cheat have a huge number of options, and it will be impossible to catch them.” Authorities at all levels, and across Russia’s 11 time zones, understand the importance of securing good numbers for the president. Acceptable figures vary “according to the levels of cynicism” of inidual actors, says Tatyana Stanovaya, director of political analysis firm RPolitik. For some, like Moscow’s mayor, Sergei Sobyanin, the target for yes votes is likely 70 per cent. For others, like Chechen president, Ramzan Kadyrov, the target will be nearer 100 per cent. “Overall, there is a sense that any result below 65 per cent would be a bad result,” Ms Stanovaya suggests.It seems a stretch to believe that the president would reach those figures in an entirely free election. A recent poll by the independent Levada Centre indicated that of those who were sure they would vote, 55 per cent would support the presidential amendments. But that figure drops below 50 per cent when it takes in all voters. Another poll by the same organisation suggested that just 25 per cent of Russians would vote for the amendments if they had a chance to vote for alternatives. Levada Centre is not the only polling organisation to register a haemorrhaging of support away from Russia’s president over recent years. How 20 years of Putin has shaped Russia and the worldAt the peak of his ratings, a year after the annexation of Crimea in June 2015, Mr Putin was supported by nine out of every 10 Russians. The same “closed” question elicits a positive answer from only 59 per cent today, and just 8 per cent of youngsters. In open polling, where respondents are asked to name the politicians they most trust for themselves – in what is considered most indicative of a free choice – Mr Putin was named by just 29 per cent of Russians. Sociologists at Levada registered the biggest falls following Mr Putin’s decision to push through unpopular pension reforms in 2018. Ms Stanovaya, however, traces the roots of an erosion of trust to 2017, when focus groups began to indicate growing disillusionment with the Kremlin’s focus on foreign campaigns in Syria and Ukraine.“The new challenges of the pandemic, low oil prices, and the constitution are catalysts for a process of erosion that began much earlier,” she says. Judging by the rush to get the vote done in the face of the pandemic, the fear among many in power would seem to be that the position is about to get even worse. “This is essentially a special operation from Putin, and special operations are all about reducing risks and mobilising quickly,” says Ms Stanovaya. “Waiting until the autumn would have meant inviting instability, the risk of a second coronavirus wave and social unrest that no one really knows how to deal with.” Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. a x Volvo XC Hybrid - in a bid to woo would-be ticket-buyers.Dale lives at the property in Ossett, West Yorks, we Katherine and their four kids, but hasnt been able to sell his property during the pandemic.And he said he quickly became fed up with estate agents.“There’s only been one viewing in the past month, so I thought it wasn’t looking good, he said,“You’ve got to think outside the box with these things.”Competitors can buy as many of the , tickets as they want.The Tate family had hoped for a quick sale as they plan to move to Australia at the end of the year.Dale, who works as an engineer, said: People havent got anything to lose really - its only £.Your odds of winning the lottery are about  million to one, but this is , to oneyou spend £.“People spend more than that on a lottery ticket and have basically no chance of winning - but this is genuine.If all the tickets sell, then somebody has to win it.“It will make somebodys day, thats for sure.We will get the asking price for it, once the fees are taken out, including stamp duty and legal fees.Its not like were over-inflating the price and trying to make a huge profit on it.“Were not doing that at all.The family plan on relocating Down Under later in  to be closer to Katherine’s family.The home is listed with raffle site RaffallStelios Kounou, who owns the site, said: When I saw a spike in ticket sales, I looked to see why and saw that it was a family home.I recognised the users name as Id spoken to him before after he successfully sold thousands of pounds worth of tools through us and the winner only paid £.Ive seen a lot of house competitions in UK fail before because they dont sell enough tickets but whats good about this one is there is no ulterior motive.Because Dale is moving abroad, he has to sell him home.House raffles arent always a success - title: secret government ufo public senate intel unidentified data
story: The Committee requested the Pentagon release all data collected on unidentied aerial phenomenon and intrusions over restricted US airspace.The call for unidentied aerial phenomena review is a big win for those who seek more transparency on what the government knows about UFOs.“Assuming the report is properly prepared and delivered, there is no telling what the impacts could be, Christopher Mellon, a former top Pentagon intelligence official and Senate staffer who has pressed for more research on the topic, told Politico. Melon continued: That could range from revealing an unknown threat or military vulnerability to there have been probes visiting our planet, or anything in between.The  annual intelligence authorization bill, which still needs to be passed by the full Senate, was submitted by acting Intelligence Committee chairman Sen. Macro Rubio and others on June , . The submission raised concerns that the government has not devoted the appropriate amount of resources to UAP.The Committee remains concerned that there is no unied, comprehensive process within the federal government for collecting and analyzing intelligence on unidentied aerial phenomena, despite the potential threat, the committee states in its report on the bill.The bill orders the Director of National Intelligence to produce a thorough report with relevant agencies, including the FBI and the Office of Naval Intelligence. The unclassied report, which may include a classied annex, will contain details about a series of encounters with UAP and advanced aerial threats. Some of those encounters may not be with extraterrestrials, but instead adversaries of America testing the nations defenses.What’s more, the report must detail what information has been previously gathered on UAPs, how the data is collected and published, and what risks UFOs could pose.In April, the Pentagon declassied and released three videos taken by US Navy pilots showing mid-air encounters with what appeared to be UFOs.One of the videos was reportedly shot in November  and the other two in January . But exactly how much will be revealed in the new report depends on what the Pentagon deems unclassied.If the bill passes, the Pentagon will have  days to submit the report to Congress.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. title: pubs reopening laws summer drinking
story: NEW laws to be rushed through within days will allow a summer of drinking in streets, car parks and other outdoor spaces to help pubs bounce back from months in lockdown.It will allow thousands more pubs, restaurants and cafes to serve customers outside by July  rather than requiring y planning applications.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe new Business and Planning Bill will also relax planning permission rules to make it easier and quicker to arrange car boot sales, summer fetes and outdoor markets.It will double the amount of time that planning permissions last for these temporary events and allow ‘temporary structures’ such as marquees and street trading stalls to stay up for up to  days.Iniduals and businesses will have greater power to use their land for temporary retail activities in a bid to inject much-needed le into local economies across England.It will also help the fight against the virus by encouraging people to be outdoors, where the risk of spreading the virus is much lower.Ministers hope it will lead to a surge in al fresco dining and drinking.Temporary chances to licensing laws will allow many more licences premises such as pubs and restaurants to sell alcohol for consumption off their premises.Customers will be able to buy their drinks from a pub and consume them where, making social distancing easier.Pubs and restaurants will be able to use car parks and terraces as dining and drinking areas - enabling customers to enjoy their drinks and food outside.Government sources said the move will given an “immediate and much-needed boost to many businesses” as they prepare to reopen on July  after  days shut during lockdown.But the Government has dropped plans to scrap Sunday Trading rules that limit the opening hours for shops after Tory rebels and Labour threatened to torpedo the whole bill.  It means the bill is likely to sail through Parliament next week - in time for the lting of lockdown measures on July .A government source said: “It’s about kickstarting this whole hospitality and retail industry beyond bricks and mortar shops over the busy summer period.“The Government will introduce new laws giving people greater freedom over how they use their land by doubling the amount of time that activities like that temporary structures can be placed on land without permission.”Meanwhile it emerged that the PM’s top aide Dominic Cummings has vowed to overhaul the civil service after concluding the Whitehall machine has been exposed by the coronavirus pandemic.The ConservativeHome website reported that he told an internal government meeting that the Cabinet Office will be stripped of powers after being found wanting during the crisis.Mr Cummings is said to have told fellow government aides: “A hard rain is coming”.Meanwhile Downing Street indicated that extra support could be offered to theatres in England which have been ordered to remain closed for live performances. The Prime Ministers official spokesman said: We are talking to the arts sector and considering ways in which we might be able to support them in addition to the unprecedented financial assistance we have already given.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beach goer cliff plunge lockdown
story: The man, , had been enjoying himself with friends when he fell onto rocks at White Beach in Anglesey.He suffered the fall at around .am today with emergency services called out to the scene.Police, paramedics, a coastguard team and the RNLI all weather leboat helped to rescue the man as water from the incoming tide approached.He was taken to Ysbyty Gwynedd hospital in Bangor.A coastguard spokesman said that the group were dealt with by police for breaking the Covid- restrictions in Wales.The clf plunge comes as thousands of Brits flocked to the country’s coastlines while temperatures sizzled to C.Crowds crammed into jam-packed beaches at Bournemouth, Brighton and Southend yesterday to soak up the sun and plenty more are expected to follow suit today.But three days of thunderstorms are predicted this weekend - bringing a wet end to Britain’s heatwave.While the beaches are packed, medics are warning against the dangers of breaking social distancing.Good Morning Britain’s Dr Hilary Jones warned Brits that coronavirus was “still out there” despite lockdown conditions being eased.He told viewers today: “I know the temptation is to go to the beach, where children can play in the water and see the boats, lovely idea, but there are plenty of open spaces that may not be quite as beautul but safer.“We’re not really out of the first wave, we’re still seeing  deaths overnight, we’re still seeing cases admitted to hospital.I don’t know what we have to say to people to say ‘stay safe’ it’s still out there and it’s too early to go back to normal.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: victory single mums dwp assessment dates
story: DWP minister Will Quince told the House of Commons that they would be issuing fresh guidance to HMRC and employers to stop people who get two paychecks in one assessment period - which wipes out their benefits for the next month.Earlier this week judges ruled that Universal Credit assessment dates are irrational and unfair after it pushed four single mums into poverty and forced them to rely on foodbanks.Today the Government said they would not fight the ruling - but there was a row over how many people could be affected.The court heard that around , claimants are left skint and out of pocket because sometimes two paydays falls into the same assessment period.But ministers said they were only aware of around , people who were affected.Mr Quince said today: We are working as quickly as we possibly can to identy the solutions on line with the court order.He added: We do recognise the budgeting issues this may have caused and we are now assessing remedial options.However, he did not give an answer for when the problem would be fixed or how, saying: This is not straightforward, it is not simply  a click of a switch.Over . million people have received Universal Credit payments since March  - just before the lockdown came into force.The number applying for the benefit has taken a steep increase thanks to coronavirus.The errors can happen when a persons monthly pay day changes because it was otherwise fall onto a weekend or bank holiday.Labours Stephen Timms said the loophole treats people asthey had had % payrise and means people have to reapply for the benefit all over again.He went on: Their income will be severely disrupted.One says she was more financially stable out of work than in work.One turned down an NHS job as she knew Universal Credit would wreck her financesNobody will dispute the view that this policy is irrational.And LaboursJonathan Reynolds said: Four single mums should not have to go to the Court of Appeal to be listened to their own government.Mum Danielle Johnson, , from West Yorkshire, was left £ a year worse off due to the loophole when she worked as a part-time dinner lady.Five million people are now receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes five weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the Government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story.Danielle and three other mums - Claire Woods, Erin Barrett and Katie Stewart - originally challenged the Department for Work and Pensionsback in .The technical blunder left all of them in rent arrears, caused them to default on council tax, saw them slapped with overdraft charges and forced to rely on foodbanks.Leigh Day lawyer, Tessa Gregory represented one of the mothers, Danielle.Tessa Gregory said today: We are delighted to learn from the discussions in Parliament this morning that the Government will not be appealing the Court’s unanimous judgment. Urgent steps must now be taken to remedy this absurd situation to ensure that no other hard-working iniduals are treated irrationally and to also ensure that those who have lost out financially are recompensed.”The DWP had initially argued that it was the fault of the employers but this has now been overturned.The government department said that fixing the issue would costs £.million and involve manually calculating benefit payments for those claimants who are affected by the loophole.Lady Justice Rose slammed the desperate situation caused by the benefit system perverse and that she cannot accept that the programme cannot be modied to make sure this doesnt happen.The problem affects those whos pay day can change depending on where a weekend or bank holiday falls in a particular month.For example, those who are paid on the last working day of the month are likely to be affected by this.Universal Credit is calculated based on your income during the same set period for every month, for example from the th of one month until the th of the next.But someone whos pay day is moved forward by a few days because their normal pay day would fall on a weekend or bank holiday could end up receiving two salary payments in one assessment period.Danielle, who was represented by Leigh Day solicitors, said: I find it unbelievable that the government has fought this case in the courts for so many years, it should not have taken the Court of Appeal to tell them something which is just a matter of common sense.The Suns Make Universal Credit Work campaign is demanding ministers make more changes to the system to help struggling Brits before its too late.We’ve told heartbreaking tales of how Brits are drowning in thousands of pounds worth of debt waiting for help, and have had to give up work due to the complicated childcare system.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s title: museums timed tickets gallery audi guides scrapped
story: Museums will be able to finally reopen on July  after a four-month shutdown, but visitors will have to follow one way routes under strict new guidelines.Museums have been told they will have to allocate timed tickets to reduce the number of people entering an exhibition or site at any one time. People probably wont be allowed to pop into a museum or gallery on a whim, as these tickets may need to be pre-booked, according to guidance from the Government. Venues should also put in one-way systems where possible, to limit the number of people moving in and out of dferent rooms. The guidance suggests implementing wait or stop signs in busy areas. Foyers and assembly areas will be used for queuing, which will have to be socially distanced. Interactive exhibitions could also have to be ditched - meaning audio guides to museums could be banned. If museums want to keep them in place, the rules suggest thorough cleaning and quarantining them to limit the risk of germs lingering after visitors have used them. The guidance says: Museumsnew formats for the content such as apps that can be accessed on personal devices or quarantine periods for public handsets. Internal shops and cafes will have to follow the same social distancing advice as those outside of museums and galleries - including quarantining clothes which people have tried on, taking orders via apps, and putting screens in front of counters to protect staff. Visiting museums and galleries could mean a long hike up stairs, as venues have been advised to limit the use of lts to people with limited mobility. This is because lts are small, enclosed spaces where the risk of spreading coronavirus is higher. Where it isnt possible to follow the  metre social distancing rule, staff and visitors will have to follow the one metre plus rule which means staying  metre away and using extra precautions such as face masks.While the advice doesnt make face masks mandatory in museums or galleries, it advises managers to consider bringing them in for staff where they think it is necessary. Heritage sites will also be subject to the advice and will need clear floor markings showing visitors through via a one-way-system to stop crowds forming. The guidance also advised heritage sites to put in similar pre-booking systems in place to limit being flooded with visitors. All cultural attractions will have to reboot their cleaning regime and implement deep cleaning, but they will have to ensure it is completed in a way that does not damage the historic fabric of the buildings.  To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vladimir putin russia vote constitutional reforms lead 36 years
story: The marathon seven-day poll is taking place in the middle of the coronavirus crisis, and would allow Putin to serve another two terms in office, remaining in power until .Putin unleashed a political storm in January with his plan to overhaul the Russian Constitution for the first time since .The official vote is scheduled for  July, but authorities opened polling stations a week early to stop overcrowding amid the pandemic - which has seen around , new confirmed cases per day.The amendments would pave the way for Putin to rule for  more years, by allowing a sitting or a former president to run for office no matter how many terms they have previously held. It would mean the -year-old would break Josef Stalins record of  years in power. Opposition activist Alexei Navalny has said the changes will allow Putin to be president for le.Putin said they will rather ensure Russias stability.The president has not publicly confirmed plans to run again in  when his current term ends - but says it is crucial he has the option.Putin said earlier this week: “Otherwise I know that in two years, instead of working normally at all levels of the state, all eyes will be on the search for potential successors.”The former KGB operative has held the reins as either president or prime minister since .From  to  Putin stepped down to the role of PM, because Russia’s rules meant be couldn’t remain as president continuously. According to current law, Putin would have to step down in  after the completion of his second six-year term.Putin is attempting to impose constitutional changes that would create an exception to the rules and allow him to run for another two years in power. If the vote goes his way, the changes would reset the clock so Putin could serve two more six-year terms after his current stint ends.It means he would remain in power until , when he would be -years-old.The reforms would additionally give the president power to nominate top judges and prosecutors for approval by Russias upper house of parliament.They would also entrench conservative measures in the constitution, including an effective ban on gay marriage and an affirmation of Russias faith in God.The amendments also includes economic guarantees, such as pledges to adjust pensions to inflation and a guaranteed minimum wage.The countrys ided opposition has failed to hold a signicant protest against the election campaign - which was given a boost by yesterdays patriotic parades for the th anniversary of victory over the Nazis.Critics are instead raising concerns about the votes legitimacy, claiming the plebiscite is a sham and that Putin intends to cling to power.They claim the vote is indeed a “veneer of democracy” on the controversial changes.Former Kremlin speechwriter-turned-political analyst Abbas Gallyamov said of the vote: “Nothing will prevent the Kremlin from getting the formal result they need.”The amendments have already been approved by both houses of parliament, the countrys Constitutional Court and were signed into law by Putin.The President has said he is confident the “absolutely majority” of Russians will approve of the changes.According to the Levada independent polling centre, % of Russians said in late May they would vote yes, and % would vote no - but only % of the no respondents planned to vote.A ‘no!’ Campaign was launched against the vote by some Moscow politicians and journalists, but the Covid- lockdown prohibited rallies.Protesters turned online, with live YouTube rallies and hashtag campaigns running on social media.They revealed a signicant number of people dont support the amendments, with one said Yulia Galyamina, one of the founders of No!One of the supporters of the ‘No!’ Campaign said despite the large number of people against the changes, they couldn’t compete with the Kremlins operation.Galyamina said: “Society is under the influence of ubiquitouspropaganda. We have neither the resources, nor the opportunity, to organise propaganda of this scale.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beaches empty beer cans rubbish sunseekers hottest day
story: In Bournemouth, where a -mile tailback formed as visitors headed for the coastline, officials slammed vile idiots who left  tonnes of litter strewn across the beach.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey blamed a breakdown in decent, civic behaviour for the appalling mass of rubbish left behind by over , visitors.Bins overflowed at resorts around the country, including in Brighton.In Dorset, a massive heap of rubbish was left piled up in the sand at beauty spot Durdle Door.  A local Councillor said the amount of rubbish left behind looked like the aftermath of a festival. Many had packed onto the citys beaches to make the most of the good weather.And today, a major incident has been declared as thousands defied advice and flocked to Bournemouth beaches on the hottest day of the year.Local officials at the popular destinations have hit out at the mess.Tobias Ellwood, the Conservative MP for Bournemouth East, said Dorset Police has slammed those who didnt take their littler home with them. He said: These are selfish people who are threatening to prolong the pandemic and also litter our beautul beaches.Vikki Slade, the leader of Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council, said: It doesnt matter what we do, these vile idiots will ignore the rules.The disgusting mess left on our beaches makes me want to weep.People urinating within sight of loos, parking illegally and just accepting the fine and ignoring the message of dont come to Dorset is a breakdown of civic behaviour.One of the litter pickers on the beach was Peter Ryan, , who founded the community group Dorset Devils.He said: It is sad, disappointing and disgusting to see the beach in such a state. It is the jewel in the crown of the area and it does not deserve to be treated like this.One personon Twitter wrote: The amount of litter left is disgusting, one that will take volunteers hours to clear. BE A DECENT HUMAN AND TAKE YOUR LITTER HOME WITH YOU!!!!Another person fumed: It is annoying seeing Bournemouth beach absolutely rammed but what proper grinds my gears is the rubbish and litter people have left behind.Beer and vodka bottles were among the debris collected this morning by litter crews.Further along the Dorset coast at Lulworth, a local councillor Laura Miller has blasted the behavior of the visitors. It was like the aftermath of a festival.Most of the visitors have come from London but others have travelled from Birmingham, Bristol and Peterborough.Meanwhile, the exclusive resort of Sandbanks in Poole saw  hours of traffic gridlock that didnt clear until pm last night.Many motorists abandoned their vehicles in the chaos.Residents on exclusive Sandbanks reported seeing people emerging from their tents in their pyjamas this morning and go to toilet in sand dunes.Stephen Allen, a resident of Sandbanks, said: It is the illegal camping that gets us. title: monkeys apes thailand lopburi
story: Locals in the city of Lopburi say the macaques primates are running rampant because the lack of tourism caused by the coronavirus lockdown has left the feral beasts starved of food.Residents have tried to help the creatures by feeding them junk food, but it is feared the sugary diet has made them sex crazed and breeding faster than before, it has been reported.Now, a sterilisation plan by authorities is underway as locals look to take back control of the streets.Before coronavirus, the humans and the primates used to live together peacefully with the monkey population believed to be as high as ,.But since the regular food supply from tourists dried up and the streets emptied, locals talk of a city where the small creatures are running riot. Local woman Kuljira Taechawattanawanna told the Daily Mail it was like being in prison: We live in a cage but the monkeys live outside.Despite the animals being outnumbered by the , humans living there, parts of the city are said to now be no-go zones. According to witnesses, the animals have turned an abandoned cinema into their headquarters where they also leave the remains of their dead love ones.Any human who attempts to enter is reportedly attacked.Residents had resorted to giving the monkeys sweets, fizzy drinks and cereal - but now fear the sugary treats have made them more hyper and sexually-active.Drastic action is now being taken by authorities who have restarted a sterilisation this month after a three-year pause. Wildle department officers plan to lure the creatures into cages and take them to a clinic, where they will be sedated, sterilised and left with a tattoo to mark their neutering. They aim to neuter  of them by Friday.It is thought there may be some pushback from residents who have grown accustomed to the monkeys, despite the problems they have caused recently. Taweesak Srisaguan, a shop owner who uses stuffed toy animals to try and scare the horde away, is wary of them disappearing completely. He said: Im used to seeing them walking around, playing on the street.If theyre all gone, Id definitely be lonely.Narongporn Daudduem from the wildle department acknowledges locals will have to give their consent. We need to do a survey of the people living in the area first.Its like dumping garbage in front of their houses and asking themtheyre happy or not.The primate presence in Lopburi previously came under the spotlight in March when a mass brawl over a single banana went viral.
