title: moment canadian mountie stomps on students head and drags her off semi conscious
story: Shocking footage shows the officer, named as Lacey Browning, dragging semi-concious student nurse Mona Wang down a carpeted hallway before stamping on her head and pulling her upper body up by her hair. Officers were called to Ms Wangs apartment in British Colombia for a welfare check, when they arrived the nursing student was found with a box cutter in her hand and surrounded by empty pill bottles, as well as an empty bottle of wine, according to Browning. Ms Wang said the Mountie physically abused her when she told her she couldnt stand up, stepping on her arm and kicking her in the stomach as per a lawsuit filed by the student on March  in British Columbia Supreme Court.The claim states: The plaintf has suffered emotional distress, humiliation, shame, and embarrassment, psychological and emotional trauma.Shocking CCTV footage released as part of the trial shows Browning dragging Ms Wang - who appears to be handcuffed - down a carpeted hallway in January this year.The woman, wearing just a bra and leggings is then pulled into a communal area close to the front door, where onlookers can be seen awkwardy walking past while the cop smiles, acting considerably more relaxed.In the footage, the Mountie appears to threaten to kick the barely-concious student in the back of her head when she raises her neck feebly, before stomping on the back of the womans skull.She then grabs fistfuls of her hair and lts her entire upper body from the ground before letting her fall. The defendant alleges Ms Wang was yelling and swinging her arms about before who proceeded to strike Wang with an open palm to subdue and arrest her under the Mental Health Act. They go on to claim the woman was a danger to herself and others and they didnt use excessive force to subdue her. According to cops, Ms Wang also swore excessively and asked to be killed.Ms Wang was taken to hospital following the incident, she said she suffered cuts, bruises and a swollen eye as a result of the alleged assault.She also said Browning told her to stop being dramatic.Speaking to CTV,Ms Wang said: I just dont understand why she felt the need to have to drag me into the lobby where everyone can see me in the middle of winter, right, and I didnt have a shirt on, I didnt have my shoes on.And I was just calling for help. It was quite dficult for people that I see on a daily basis walking past, seeing me in such a vulnerable state.I definitely think that when police get in a situation like that their instinct is to use violence.A spokesperson for RCMP said the officer is on administrative leave and the Mounties will ask an outside police department to review the findings.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast record temperature hottest day year
story: The temperature at in London around pm on Thursday hit .C, breaking the record set the day before, the Met Office said.Heathrow has matched yesterdays .C and is likely to rise further this afternoon, the Met Office tweeted at pm.The temperature then climbed to .C an hour later.The scorching sunshine is expected to give way to sweeping thunderstorms from this evening, bringing heavy rain, lightning and hail.Thunderstorms broke out across South West England around .pm.Storms will form also form in South East England, Wales, western Scotland and Northern Ireland.A yellow weather warning for thunderstorms is in place for much of the country from Thursday to Saturday, warning of disruption due to flooding, lightning strikes, hail and wind.Today, West London is forecast to see temperatures peak between Cand C .Parts of Wales could see the mercury rise to C- making it the hottest June on record in the country, surpassing the previous peak of .Con June , .Beachgoers travelled to the water in huge numbers again on Thursday.Camber Sands beach was so popular that police were forced to close the road leading to the shore at .am due to heavy traffic.In Bournemouth, a major incident was declared as thousands defied advice and flocked to beaches.Emergency crews were left completely overstretched by Brits packing out the shoreline.The public have been slammed by the local council for blocking roads, boozing and dumping rubbish at Bournemouth beach.Meanwhile, a thrillseeker brazenly ignored warning signs and barged threw a safety fence before flinging himself off the top of Durdle Door on the Dorset coast - just weeks after three men were seriously injured doing the same.In Cornwall, an urgent warning was issued after five popular holiday beaches were swamped by raw sewage.A woman died on the beach at Worthing in West Sussex, after desperate attempts to save her le were unsuccessful.An air ambulance helicopter landed on the beach around noon after the woman suffered a medical episode according to police.The Met Office has raised its heat alert level to three and as health authorities have urged sun seekers to protect themselves amid the exceptionally hot weather forecast this week.Forecasters have also warned people can get sunburnt in just  minutes.Public Health England said older people, those with underlying health conditions, and very young children were all more at risk from the higher temperatures.People have been advised to keep cool and stay hydrated where possible.The UK faces its highest-ever UV levels today due to the lack of pollution from planes.Ultra-violet rays are expected to reach level nine across parts of Devon and Cornwall.Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said that UV levels will be reaching eight across many places and will be reaching nine across parts of Devon and Cornwall today.He said: Thats about as high as it gets really in the UK. The sun is as strong as it gets at the moment because were so close to the solstice.Weve got peak sun strength, clear skies, plenty of sunshine - theyre the perfect ingredients for high UV.Dr Michaela Hegglin, associate professor in atmospheric chemistry at the University of Readings Department of Meteorology, said Thursday could see some of the highest UV levels ever recorded in Britain.She said: This is because of a combination of factors. We are at the summer solstice, when the sun is almost directly overhead at one oclock.UV levels this high are rare in the UK, so people with light skin should be very careful to avoid getting burnt.While UV is important for getting vitamin D and keeping us healthy, too much of it can cause skin cancer or eye cataracts.Emer OConnell, consultant in public health at PHE, said it was important that people kept checking on the vulnerable, as many continued to spend more time at home due to coronavirus.You will need to do things dferently this year, for example keeping in touch by phone, she said.If you need to provide direct care to someone at risk from hot weather, follow Government guidance on how to do this safely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: star spangled banner francis scott key national anthem
story: Here is more on the evolution of the song and its controversial origins.The patriotic Star-Spangled Banner is a song that includes lyrics written early in the th century.The words come from a poem written about the bombardment of Fort McHenry in Maryland by the British in  during the War of .The poem has four stanzas, but only the first one is usually performed before sporting events and other gatherings.The lyrics were written by Francis Scott Key, a lawyer and author who witnessed the bombardment.He wrote a poem titled Defense of Fort McHenry after the Battle of Baltimore concluded.Key was apparently inspired by the US victory and the flag flying over the fort.The words to the poem were later set to the music for the British song To Anacreon in Heaven.Key was a slaveholder who believed Blacks are an inferior race of people, according to the Smithsonian magazine.He served as the district attorney for the city of Washington from  to  and defended slavery during his tenure.He was also a close adviser of President Andrew Jackson.Virtually every American knows the name Francis Scott Key, biographer Marc Leepson told The Baltimore Sun in .But they know just one thing about him.There was a lot more to the man than just that he wrote The Star-Spangled Banner under dramatic circumstances.Key writes in the third verse of his historic poem that the foul footsteps of slaves who fought with the British have polluted America.My students really struggled with that line, author and former teacher Karsonya Wise Whitehead told The Baltimore Sun in .Only the first of four stanzas is usually performed:O say can you see, by the dawns early light,What so proudly we haild at the twilights last gleaming,Whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fightOer the ramparts we watched were so gallantly streaming And the rockets red glare, the bomb bursting in air,Gave proof through the night that our flag was still there,O say does that star-spangled banner yet waveOer the land of the free and the home of the brave The song was made the national anthem in  when Congress passed a measure declaring it so.It had been recognized for official use by the US Navy in , and by President Woodrow Wilson in .Over the years there have been many memorable performances, including by Whitney Houston at the  Super Bowl. Others have famously botched the song, including actress and comic Roseanne Barr.In recent years NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick and other athletes have kneeled in protest during the national anthem to protest racial inequality and injustice in the US.Kaepernick has had trouble finding a team to play for.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hero teen odney weir
story: Jack Staunton and Ralph Sewell, both , ed into the water at the beauty spot to help the swimmer after he failed to resurface. The brave teenagers had been relaxing with a group of friends at Odney Weir, in Cookham, Berks., on Tuesday when the tragedy hit. The body of dad-of-five Eyad Al Ryabi, who is also believed to have jumped in to try to save his friend, was found by emergency service teams at the scene on Wednesday. His friend, in his s, who has not been named, was rushed to hospital where he remains in a serious condition. Eyad moved to the UK from Syria towards the end of last year to try to make a better le for his family, his relative said.Both boys describe seeing a group of men jumping into deep parts of the water in jeans and t-shirts. Jack, from Maidenhead, told The Sun: “They were part of this big group, all swimming and messing around like we were. “One of them jumped over the Weir, and got sucked in. We are pretty sure he was knocked unconscious under the water and he didn’t come back up again. “Ralph and I saw what was happening and we climbed over and started trying to pull him out. “His friend also climbed over and tried to pull him out, he was unconscious. “We were telling them to pull his head out of the water, and Ralph was trying to do that and had a hold of him and was swimming alongside him. “His friend then lost his grip on him and he started getting pushed down the river because of the current. “A fisherman jumped in and helped us to grab him and pull him out to put him on the side of the river. “That was when someone  started to perform CPR on him, the ambulance service were telling them what to do on the phone. “I tried to do CPR but I wasn’t strong enough so I asked for help. “After all of this another one of his friends had tried to save him by grabbing the leguard ring and ing in. “We were all focusing on the first man we didn’t realise the second one had been swept away.“Because my friends and I go there quite a lot we know to avoid the middle of the river because of the hotspots. “But these guys didn’t know where they shouldn’t jump and got sucked into the current.“I’ve been going there for a long time and nothing like this has ever happened before.”Ralph added: “A group of us were at the weir and suddenly I heard the guys screaming, three of them were in the water and one was unconscious. “They were trying to get him out, and when I heard the screaming I jumped in and climbed down the weir and tried to help them pull him out. “His head was really under the water, his friend seemed to lose his grip on him and he went even further under the water. “As he went down the river someone helped us to get him on the bank and then an older guy performed CPR on him. “I’m glad he’s alive, I know he’s in the hospital but I hope he is okay. There was a lot going on at that moment. “The part that they jumped into was probably the most dangerous part of the weir, we did try to find his friend but we didn’t want to risk it when we know what the currents are like. “It’s generally a pretty safe place to go and swim but I don’t think we will be going back there again.”Both boys jumped back in to try to save Syrian refugee Eyad after he had also tried to save his pal. Other members of the Syrian community in West London also travelled to the riverbank after learning their friend, , who lives in Uxbridge, had gone missing.Jacks mum Nicola Thomas said: “It’s heartbreaking for the boys to see all of this, and for the family of the man that it’s happened to. “I didn’t know whether to shout at Jack or hug him at first, because he’s put himself in danger jumping in but I am proud of him. “They definitely saved his le, there is no doubt about that.”The tragedy came as temperatures soared to around C on Tuesday as Britains heatwave continues.Officials from the Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service said crews were at the riverside for almost three-and-a-half hours.A spokesman said: We are urging residents across Berkshire to take care near water.As the warm weather continues, it may be tempting to swim in open water, but there are many dangers involved.One of the main risks when entering the water is cold water shock, eventhe weather is warm.You also do not know what is beneath the surface – there could be unseen currents and reeds, which could pull you under.”LPA Commander for Windsor  Maidenhead, Superintendent Colin Hudson, said: “Officers have been working tirelessly with our partners to locate the man who entered the water yesterday, and have now tragically found a body.“We are grateful for the support we received from both Berkshire and Buckinghamshire Fire and Rescue Services, South Central Ambulance Service, and Berkshire Lowland Search and Rescue.“I would also like to thank members of the public who provided information as well as assistance to my officers.“I would like to thank them for their patience while officers investigated this incident, and we will be leaving the scene shortly.“I am very sorry to have to bring this sad news.“Our thoughts are with both men’s families during this very upsetting time.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur title: ikea bookcase topple over children california
story: A baby camera in Nicole Oka’s home in Calornia captured what happened to the two-year-olds on June .The video shows the twins climbing on the bookcase in their bedroom after being put to bed.Soon, the bookcase can be seen crashing down on them — despite Oka believing the dresser was screwed into the wall.The kids are heard screaming and soon, the children’s parents rush in to get them.Oka told USA Today: “I remember being so afraid of this happening. It felt like a very real thing that could happen to me.”“My babies could have died,” the mother said. “I did everything right. I did everything I should have.”Oka toldwhat happened was “traumatic” and said she ran to the children as soon as what saw the incident on the baby camera.The mother and her husband, Dan, bought the bookcase in  and said they understood it could be a potential hazard — so they bought brackets to keep it flat against the wall.Ikea spokesperson Hanna Bengtsander said in a statement that the company was investigating what happened.“We are currently reviewing the video involving the Brimnes bookcase and need more time to get a better understanding of the details,” she said, adding they couldn’t provide further comment at the time.According to USA Today, at least  children have died from furniture tip-over accidents since .Ikea dressers specically have caused at least five deaths since , per the report.In , Ikea recalled .million dressers that didn’t meet the required safety standards, and acknowledged the fact.• February : A -month-old boy from Apple Valley, Minn. died after an unanchored MALM -drawer chest fell on top of him.• July : A -month-old girl from Mount Vernon, Virginia, died after an unanchored Gute -drawer chest tipped over and pinned her against the footboard of a youth bed.In , Ikea sold another dresser that didn’t meet the voluntary stability standard for  weeks before it was recalled in March.The dresser that fell on the twins earlier this month, according to USA Today, was recalled in .The Brimnes bookshelf was over six feet high and included two drawers at the bottom, with four shelves.In January, Ikea agreed to pay million to the parents of Jozef Dudek, a two-year-old boy who died in  after a -pounds recalled dresser tipped over onto him.The boy died of his injuries and his parents sued Ikea, accusing the Swedish company of knowing the specic dresser posed a hazard, but that the company failed to warn consumers about it.The Dudek family said they would donate million from the settlement to organizations that advocate for more rigorous stability testing for dressers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: california disneyland reopening delayed
story: However, the grand opening has been delayed due to renewed fears over the coronavirus pendemic.Heres more about the delayed reopening of the world-famous tourist attraction.The reopening will remain postponed until further notice.On Friday, Disneyland Parks News said in a statement: “While there is still much uncertainty with respect to the impacts of COVID-, the safety and well-being of our guests and employees remains The Walt Disney Company’s top priority.The delay was enforced because the theme park did not think that it could reach an approval from the state and the union in time.“Given the time required for us to bring thousands of cast members back to work and restart our business, we have no choice but to delay the reopening of our theme parks and resort hotels until we receive approval from government officials,” said the company.Yet, Disney still plans on reopening its Downtown Disney shopping district on July .Disneys Grand Calornian Hotel and Spa and its Paradise Pier Hotel, both part of the Disneyland resort, are looking to reopen on July .Disneyland resort will reopen with enhanced health and safety measures, the company said, adding that the park will be signicantly limited to comply with governmental requirements and promote physical distancing.Shanghai Disneyland recently reopened and quickly sold out its first two weeks of greatly reduced available tickets.Walt Disney Co. CEO Bob Chapek previously said no park would be reopenedit was forecast to lose money.The COVID- cases are specically on the rise in Florida, where Disneyworld is located.So far, there are over , confirmed cases and almost , deaths in the state.Despite Florida’s governor voicing concern, the Downtown Disney district in Orlando, Florida, will start its reopening on July .Disneyworld was slammed for hosting a farewell party on March , before it was set to close.Abigail Disney, grandaughter of Roy Disney – who was a co-founder of the Florida theme park – was among those who criticized the party.Are you f***ing kidding me, she tweeted, quoting a picture of the crowded park. A union representing Disneyland’s hotel and restaurant workers were planning a protest to reopen the grounds due to safety concerns over the virus outbreak.Also, a coalition representing , Disneyland workers sent Calornia Governor Gavin Newsom a letter last week expressing concerns about safety protocols for the reopening.Calornia reported a record of , infections with Disneyland’s home of Orange County showing the fourth-biggest increase in the state, at , cases.According to Lynch, the union negotiator, Disney will not pay for virus testing for employees, and that is not considering those who do not have health-care coverage.“What happens when one person in a department gets coronavirus ” Lynch said in an interview. “Do they shut everything down  Until they answer, they should not be allowed to reopen,” she said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: west end stars should give back
story: I BELIEVE Boris Johnson when he says the thing he is looking forward to most as we emerge from our enforced national hibernation is taking in some Shakespeare at the Globe theatre.Butthe Prime Minister is not careful that’s an option that might not be available to him.I’m less of a culture vulture when it comes to high arts, but my heart aches to go to one of my beloved West End musicals. I mean, I’ve only been able to see Dear Evan Hansen  times so far.And Christmas won’t be the same without the uniquely British tradition of the winter panto. How will all those former boyband stars fund their showbiz lestyles for another year Sadly, post-Covid restrictions look particularly cruel to the arts.Those dastardly droplets mean singing is banned and the idea of packing out a historic theatre where the tiny seats mean you are virtually sitting on top of your neighbour just won’t cut it.But in the middle of an international health emergency it’s all too easy to dismiss the importance of stage shows, movies, the TV industry, festivals and concerts.The attitude seems to be: “We’re dying, goddammit, the economy is cratering, don’t talk to me about the bloody theatre!”But that approach will mean Britain is cakewalking into a cultural catastrophe that could wipe off decades of creative progress, end our modern domination of the arts and entertainment and see the closure of most historic theatres before the end of the year.If that is yet another horrid consequence of Covid-, a disease most likely spread because of a despicable Chinese wet market, I will be fuming.Yesterday’s warning from Dame Judi Dench, who is , that theatres may not open again in her letime is as stark as it is horrying.It would wipe out £.billion of annual ticket sales, see , good folk lose their jobs and damage tourism.While the pressure is building by the day on the Government to launch yet another unprecedented rescue package, I think that’s only part of the answer.Entertainment is a big-money industry dominated by super-wealthy moguls who have a responsibility to look after as many of their loyal staff and young creatives as humanly possible.Now is the time for other celebrities and businesspeople who have earned a small fortune from the creative industries to give back.Where are all those Hollywood stars, with hundreds of millions in the bank, who rush to perform on the West End stage to be seen as a real actor, dahling Surely they could donate a tiny portion of their wealth to set up a private rescue fund for theatres For example, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the South Park creators who are behind The Book Of Mormon, are worth a billion bucks.JK Rowling, whose Harry Potter play The Cursed Child is at the Palace Theatre, has a £million fortune.We Will Rock You producer Robert de Niro has £million in the bank, Sister Act producer and star Whoopi Goldberg £million, and West End favourite Dame Helen Mirren £million.I could name a hundred other multi-millionaire stars who have used the West End to enhance their careers who owe it to the backroom staff on the breadline to be part of the solution.Thankfully, the king of theatre — Lord Lloyd-Webber — has, as ever, proved inspirational and innovative.Without being asked, he is putting his money where his mouth is to PROVE to the Government that it is possible to safely reopen theatres WITHOUT ANY social distancing by using enhanced precautions such as temperature checks on the door and face masks for all audience members.The Government must listen to him and embrace his case study of Phantom Of The Opera, which has remained open in South Korea throughout the pandemic with no issues.Otherwise, we risk the curtain coming down for good.BACKING down so quickly on extending Sunday trading hours was a disappointing move forced by Tory backbenchers.While on first glance the idea of allowing supermarkets and other shops to stay open longer on our day of rest sounds unappealing to many workers, the reality is that this change would have probably saved many jobs in the long run.It’s nonsensical that on one day of the week most Tescos can only open for six hours, while international delivery services such as Amazon continue to decimate their business, especially now with social-distancing measures making it even more unappealing to spend time lining up outside.By contrast, the other night I was able to order an Amazon Prime Now delivery to arrive at my house at pm on a Sunday night.I’d ordered an Uber Eats takeaway from McDonald’s two hours earlier.The archaic current trading hours laws were introduced in , the year Jeff Bezos created a fledgling online book store called Amazon.Like it or not, that business has created a dferent world of consumerism.Compromises to allow workers the option not to take on more Sunday work, leaving the additional hours to those who want to earn extra cash, could make the necessary move more palatable.But let’s not avoid having the debate.THE Culture Secretary has so much on his plate that Shirley Ballas used an innovative approach to attract his attention this week – and it worked.Launching an impassioned plea to Oliver Dowden to “safely open” ballroom dance studios on my talkRADIO Drivetime show, the Strictly Come Dancing judge teased: “If Oliver is out there, I don’t even mind having a cha-cha-cha with him to show him it is possible to social distance.”Clearly the power of the Queen of Latin remains undiminished.Within hours, Oliver had tweeted: “Shirley, as a Strictly fan, I’m happy to talk about how we can get dancing going safely again. Great offer on the cha-cha-cha – I’ll get practising.”Expect dance studios to be back in business imminently, then.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: holiday july 4 sign off
story: Boris Johnson will meet with First Secretary Dominic Raab and Transport Secretary Grant Shapps to iron out the final plans to allow Brits to go on holiday quarantine free.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIndustry sources expect Brits will be able to start flying abroad from July .But those ing will still have to fill out a quarantine ‘landing card’ even though there will be no requirement to self isolate from countries deemed safe.The details will be kept for test and trace purposes, in case of an outbreak on a flight, ferry or train journey from the continent.It’s understood they will sign off on agreements holiday favourites including France, Italy and Spain, as well as other European nations.The aviation industry has been fiercely critical of the quarantine measures introduced on June  and has welcomed the air bridge plans.But the travel industry body Abta urged the Government to set out its plans as soon as possible to allow businesses and customers to plan ahead.An Abta spokesman said: The process of sending people on holiday is not like turning on a tap. As much advance notice as possible from the Government is required for travel companies to restart operations. Greek tourism minister Haris Theoharis said the country wanted British tourists towhen it opens to other European holidaymakers on July .He said: The final decision, from the UK and our point of view, will be in place in the next few days and Im hoping the announcement will be positive from both sides. He told BBC Radio s Today programme there was no need for those ing to the UK from Greece to be quarantined and added: The point is that Greece is a safe country - we have proven that during this crisis and we will continue proving this in the exit stages of the health situation.”The safe travel corridors will be set up after the quarantine review on June  and the Foreign Office will change their travel advice from “against all but essential international travel” to allow travel to these safe nations.France, Spain, Italy, Germany, Austria, Greece, Belgium, Netherlands, Gibraltar, Bermuda, and possibly Portugal will all be announced in the first batch of ‘safe nations.’There will also be a “slow trickle” of updated destinations from then, with medium haul destinations, like Turkey and Dubai added towards August.Long haul flights will be back on the cards from mid to late summer, with trips to Vietnam, Singapore, and Hong Kong given the ok.Officials are also working on an ambitious plan to allow travel from Australia without having to quarantine providing flights have not been in transit in high risk countries.But the USA, Mexico and South American countries are set to be off limits until the end of the year.  Dont miss the latest news and figures - and essential advice for you and your family.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out moreGOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: major incident bournemouth beaches hottest
story: Emergency crews have been left completely overstretched by Brits packing out the shoreline today. Police have been seen on Bournemouth beach speaking with coastguards as reinforcements have been called in to tell people to stay away. Emergency crews were also abused as they attempted to clean overflowing bins on the seafront - with eight tonnes of waste collected yesterday.Today, a further  tonnes of rubbish was dumped on the beaches.The public have been slammed by the local council for blocking roads, boozing and dumping rubbish at Bournemouth beach.Thousands have also descended on Lulworth and Durdle Door, where two tombstoners were seriously injured earlier this month.Bournemouth Council today confirmed a major incident has been declared to tackle the problem.Sunseekers had been asked to stay away from the beaches but are now flouting coronavirus lockdown rules.Poole and Bournemouth hospitals have announced they are to co-coordinating resources across the area to tackle the impact of extremely crowded beaches.Council Leader Vikki Slade said: “We are absolutely appalled at the scenes witnessed on our beaches, particularly at Bournemouth and Sandbanks, in the last - hours. The irresponsible behaviour and actions of so many people is just shocking and our services are stretched to the absolute hilt trying to keep everyone safe. We have had no choice now but to declare a major incident and initiate an emergency response.”The council say large numbers of visitors descended on beaches as the mercury soared to C - causing illegal parking, excessive waste, anti-social behaviour, gridlock on roads and prohibited overnight camping.They were forced to hand out  parking fines - the highest on record - and compared the crowds to being like those seen on a bank holiday.Bournemouth MP Tobias Ellwood said there were dispersal orders in place on both piers to break up the crowds.He tweeted: MAJOR INCIDENT’ declared in BOURNEMOUTH - pls stay away.With   million visitors in Dorset, roads are gridlocked, hindering emergency vehicles  beaches are full - with Dispersal Orders on both piers.I’ve asked Police Minister to dispatch additional policeDorset requests.Dorset Police have now urged people to stay away from the seaside amid the current coronavirus pandemic.Sam de Reya, the Assistant Chief Constable of Dorset Police, said: These are unprecedented times and we are urging people to stay away from the area of Bournemouth beach and other Dorset beaches.We are also deploying additional resources to provide increased patrols in the vicinity to help tackle any issues of anti-social behaviour and other offences being committed.The declaration of a major incident allows us to bring agencies together so we can take actions available to us to safeguard the public as much as possible.We strongly advise members of the public to think twice before heading to the area. Clearly we are still in a public health crisis and such a signicant volume of people heading to one area places a further strain on emergency services resources.Locals in plush Sandbanks now say police should have set up roadblocks when the area reaches capacity to avoid crowds gathering.And some beach bosses now want to call in the army to help cope with the swell in visitors.Southend-on-Sea councillor Ron Woodley said: If we cant get enough police then get the armed forces on the streets.We dont want to be in a military state but we want to be safe andwe havent got police resources, what other resources have we got It comes as sunseekers flocked to beaches across the UK today to enjoy the heatwave.Temperatures hit .C today at Heathrow - beating Wednesdays high of .C to officially make it the hottest day of the year.Camber Sands beach was so popular that police were forced to close the road leading to the shore at .am due to heavy traffic.In Cambridgeshire, police have put a -hour dispersal order in place in Houghton to stop people jumping in the water to cool off.Yesterday, there was a -mile tailback formed as visitors headed for the coastline in Dorset.Council chiefs condemned vile idiots who left rubbish strewn on the beach and blamed a breakdown in decent, civic behaviour.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: raf aircraft bird strike
story: Pictures of the damaged Airbus AM show the unlucky birds blood and feathers - which managed to rupture the side of the RAF plane.The animal struck the side of the aircraft mid-flight, causing a giant hole in the military plane just under the cockpit.Feathers from the bird could be seen both inside and outside of the flight-deck - with blood splatters seen near internal cables.No one - apart from the poor bird - was injured in the splat, and the aircraft landed safely. The Airbus AM Atlas is specically designed for military transport and is used in German, French and Spanish Air Forces.Its operations include cargo and troop transport, as well as medical evaluation transport.The AM boasts four-engines and has been part of the RAF since .However, this isnt the first time an AM airlter has been involved in a bird strike.Earlier this year in May, the same aircraft model used by the Spanish Air Force was damaged by a flying bird whilst flying near Madrid.There were no injuries, but the aircraft suffered signicant damage near the lower shaft of the body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: el chapo mexico lawless
story: Pictures of the armed members of the Sinaloa Cartel, famously headed by drug lord El Chapo, were captured in the north-eastern Mexican state of Durango.The mountainous region, which is a major producer of Mexican opium and cannabis, is often referred to as the ‘Golden Triangle’ - because its where the states of Sinaloa, Chihuahua and Durango meet.According to local media, the cartel has taken over the area in Durango and established it as a sanctuary for its leaders.Free from cops, the cartel leaders can walk liberally through the streets surrounded by their heavily armed troops.The footage shows a long line of armed men lining a street holding machine guns and wearing bullet-proof vests while shouting: “Up Durango.”The troops are believed to belong to Los Cabrera, who are the armed wing of the Sinaloa Cartel, headed by Jose Luis Cabrera Sarabia.The armed wing, also involved in drug trafficking, executions, and extortion, were also found to be recruiting minors into its ranks, according to an investigation by the Ministry of National Defense.Jose Luis brother, Felipe Cabrera Sarabia, nicknamed ‘The Engineer’ and ‘Lord of the Mountains’, recently pleaded not guilty against charges of drug trafficking in an ongoing trial in the United States after he was extradited from Mexico.According to local media, Cabrera Sarabia was the head guard of notorious drug Lord ‘El Chapo’ Guzman.El Chapo was caged for le in  after being found guilty of trafficking cocaine, heroin and marijuana - and was also engaged in murder conspiracies during his time as the notorious drug lord.Earlier this week, at least ten bodies were dumped on a roadside in Mexico as a new bloody gang war erupted in Sonora.Those slaughtered were said to be members of a criminal gang led by Rafael Caro Quintero.Some of the men found dead had their hand tied behind their back while others were discovered shirtless on the pavement.The armed gang also torched a nearby gas station as well as a number of homes and vehicles.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Ministers have revealed their plans for an al fresco revolution to encourage open air shopping and drinking throughout the summer to control coronavirus.Brits will see big changes as pubs take over Britainaposs pavements and landlords encourage people to buy a pint to drink where. And while the Government and pub owners are hopeful that weaposre going to flock back to pubs, it looks like it is going to be a very dferent experience. The Prime Minister has given the go-ahead for pubs, restaurants and hotels to reopen as of next month - albeit with social distancing restrictions in place - while non-essential retail is already free to resume selling. It will be easier for pubs to change how they work It is a bit technical, but it is the change that makes all the other bits possible. The bill will change the way pubs ask local councils for permission on changing how they open. It will reduce the consultation period for applications for pavement licences to from  calendar days to  working days, and grant consent after  working daysthe council does not issue a decision And it lowers application fee for a pavement and street cafe licence to just £.  Get used to being outside With a hard limit on the number of people allowed to be inside a pub at any given time, you wonapost be propping up the bar anytime soon. In fact you wonapost be allowed to - inside people will have to be sat at a table to enjoy a drink. But perhaps the most noticeable change youaposll see at your local under under proposals laid out in the Business and Planning Bill, is that outside seating will become the norm. And to make that easier any outside areas that a pub has control over, like a car park, will be allowed to turn into seating areas.  You can take a pint homeAs part of the plans unveiled on Thursday, licensed premises will be able to serve booze for punters to take away and consume where in efforts to stop drinkers crowding indoors. While some pubs did this before and may have relied on it to keep themselves afloat during the lockdown, more pubs than ever will sell drinks for you to take home or drink off-premises in a bid to keep people as distanced as possible. More drinking space on the pavement outside pubs As part of the bill, Ministers are hoping to change how pubs get permission to set up on the pavements outside their doors. It will let a licence-holder to place removable furniture over certain highways adjacent to the premises. This is a streamlined process to allow businesses to secure these licences in time for the summer and allow these licences to remain in place for a year but not beyond  September   Youaposll also see more outdoor markets Meanwhile, outdoor markets, summer fairs and car boot sales will no longer need planning permission, meaning their hours can be extended without prior approval. Scientists have found that Covid- does not spread as easily in an outside environment compared to when indoors, meaning an outdoor lestyle could help keep the infection rate under control when lockdown measures are signicantly eased on July .

title: government refuses say lockdown changes
story: NewsNo refuses to saylockdown changes could push R number above Boris Johnsons spokesman refused to say what,anything, SAGE said about how Englands lockdown easing will affect the dreaded rate of infectionShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSouthend beach on the hottest day of the year " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDowning Street has refused to saysweeping changes to Englandaposs lockdown could push the dreaded aposRapos number above one. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman refused to be drawn on the topic after it was missing from the PMaposs statement opening pubs, restuarants, bars, cinemas, hotels, campsites, hairdressers and places of worship.The reproduction number - aposRapos for short - is the average number of people who get infected by each person with coronavirus.If itaposs higher than one, the virus starts spreading exponentially and can run out of control.A month ago, when Boris Johnson schools and non-essential shops would reopen, he explicitly said the changes should keep aposRapos below one.But this time, when he revealed lockdown would ease on Tuesday, he did not repeat that claim. Instead the PM focused on the aposfive testsapos for easing lockdown to justy reopening huge areas of English society. Today Mr Johnsonaposs spokesman was askedhis scientic advisors had set out advice on how the new changes would affect aposRapos. But he refused to say. Instead he told journalists: As the PM set out, we believe the five tests continue to be met and that was the basis for reaching the decision.  “In terms of the R rate, the R rate for England under the most recently announced figures was . to ..” Asked again what the scientistsapos advice was, he told journalists: You don’t need to take my word for it - both Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty were asked extensively earlier this week for their views on the package and they articulated them in full. Told the pair had not been asked a specic question about aposRapos, he replied: What they said is it was a reasonable balance of risk informed by reasonable professional judgements.  It comes after a leaked Public Health England briefing suggested the R number could already be above one in parts of England.The document, obtained by HuffPost UK, said because of uncertainty in how accurate the figure is, “we cannot preclude R being above ”.A previous model suggested it was already at or above one in the North West and South West - but the government insisted that model was only one of more than ten. The R number was put at the centre of the governmentaposs communications about easing lockdown in May. When he reopened schools and non-essential shops, the PM told England on May : This package has been carefully designed so that we can ease the burdens of lockdown, while expecting to keep that R below one. I cannot and will not throw away all the gains we have made together. And so the changes we are making are limited and cautious.

Robert Jenrick faces questions over his decision to approve a £bn housing development in London against the advice of a planning inspector. He gave Westferry Printworks, planned by billionaire Tory donor Richard Desmond, the green light on January  - hours before a council levy kicked in that would have cost the developer around £m. Itaposs since emerged Mr Desmond showed the minister a video of the scheme on his phone at a Tory fundraising dinner in November, and texted him asking him to approve it before the deadline. The new messages show that on November , Mr Desmond told him we donapost want to give Marxists in Tower Hamlets council loads of doe for nothing. In an e-mail dated January , a government official then said Mr Jenrick was insistent that decision issued this week ie tomorrow - as next week the viability of the scheme is impacted by the levy. Mr Desmond is not accused of wrongdoing, and Mr Jenrick has insisted that while there could have been an appearance of bias, there was no actual bias. Even so, the minister cancelled his approval to avoid a perception of bias in favour of the scheme. Downing Street today said the Prime Minister still had full confidence in Mr Jenrick, even though Mr Johnson spoke to the minister in recent days.

title: two super earths found orbiting
story: NewsTwo super-Earths found orbiting bright red dwarf star just  light years awaySuper-Earths have been found orbiting a red dwarf star cool enough to possibly allow surface water on an orbiting planet. Scientists say it could become one of the most studied planetary systems in the Solar neighbourhoodShareCommentsByNilima MarshallJoseph WilkesReporter:,  JUN News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo super-Earths have been discovered orbiting one of the brightest red dwarf stars in the sky. About half as big as the Sun, GJ  is just  light years away. Red dwarfs like GJ  have low surface temperatures, which makes them less luminous and often hard to detect. But stars like these are cooler than the Sun, which means the habitable zone - the orbital band where temperatures are mild enough to allow liquid surface water on orbiting planets - is much closer to GJ  in comparison with the Earthaposs distance from the Sun. The new planets, called GJ b and GJ c, were found using a high-precision, planet-finding instrument on the European Southern Observatoryaposs .-metre telescope at La Silla in Chile. Both are believed to be super-Earths - planets which have a mass higher than Earth but substantially below those of local ice giants Uranus and Neptune. The discovery was made by an international team of astronomers, including researchers from the University of Hertfordshire, The Open University and Queen Mary University of London. The scientists used a technique known as Doppler wobble, which enabled them to find the planets by measuring their gravitational interaction with GJ . As a planet orbits, it causes its parent star to wobble by a tiny degree. Astronomers can see the signature of this effect in the light emitted by the star. The researchers believe both GJ b and GJ c lie close to the inner edge of habitable zone and may be too hot to maintain liquid water on their surfaces. They estimate the surface temperature of GJ c, which takes . days to circle its host star, to be around C. GJ b, meanwhile, is much closer to the star, with an orbital period of . days. But the researchers say GJ  is less active than other red dwarfs, so the newly discovered worlds may be spared from strong stellar winds - outflowing material from the star which can erode a planetaposs atmosphere. Hence, the team are keen to learn more about this super-Earth system. Dr John Barnes, an astrophysicist at the Open University and one of the authors on the study published in the journal Science, said: Close orbiting planets like these have a high chance of being tidally locked to their host star. This means that as the planet orbits its star, the same hemisphere always faces the star. For the planets orbiting GJ , half of the planets would be in perpetual daytime and the other half in perpetual night time. So, it could be much cooler on some parts of the planets than others. The researchers also detected an unconfirmed signal, raising hopes of a third planet with a more temperate orbit. But Dr Barnes is cautious about this finding, saying: If the signal is a planet, it would orbit every  days.

Emergency services were called to Loch Lubnaig, near Callander, Scotland, at .pm on Wednesday but were unable to save the youngster. Michael Heeps was from High Valleyfield in Fe and his family have today paid touching tribute to the much-loved youngster. They said: He was a much loved son, brother, grandson, nephew and cousin x Dozens of tributes were posted on social media by heartbroken friends and family. Cousin Emma Fraser wrote: Hearts breaking. R. I. P to my little cousin. fly high wee man. Another friend wrote: Thinking of the family. How tragic. God bless wee man. In England, two men got into dficulty at a weir in Cookham, Berkshire. One man was pulled from the water and taken to hospital in a serious condition, while another remained missing. Sadly, after a  hour search, Thames Valley Police confirmed a body had been found. Officers were called Lulle Brook, between Odney Lane and Mill Lane, in Cookham,  Maidenhead  on Tuesday night around pm.They attended alongside fire crews from both Royal Berkshire and Buckinghamshire Fire and Rescue services, South Central Ambulance Service, and Berkshire Lowland Search and Rescue. Hero Connor Godfrey was fishing on the weir in Cookham, Berkshire, yesterday evening and described how playful shouts turned to panicked screaming as two men got into dficulty. The chef said kids had been jumping from the weir into the gushing water below all afternoon, as well as a group of men later in the day.

Professor Whitty warned that cases will spikepeople do not follow social distancing guidance. It comes as a major incident was at Bournemouth#xs beaches as thousands of visitors flocked to the south coast to enjoy the hot weather. In a Tweet Professor Whitty wrote: #xCCOVID- has gone down due to the efforts of everyone but is still in general circulation.#xCIf we do not follow social distancing guidance then cases will rise again. Naturally people will want to enjoy the sun but we need to do so in a way that is safe for all.#xDProfessor Whitty warned that cases will spikepeople do not follow social distancing guidance. Read more here:Nursery outbreak as  children, parents and staff test positiveA flare-up of coronavirus at a nursery in Milton Keynes has led to  new confirmed cases.Dozens of staff, children and family members linked to Acorn nursery in Westcroft have tested for the deadly bug over the past week and a half, according to MK Citizen.All staff and families at the nursery are now being offered testing for Covid- as a precaution.The outbreak has led to a plea from officials to follow social distancing rules as lockdown restrictions are relaxed.Muriel Scott, Director of Public Health for Milton Keynes, said it was #xCvitally important#xD to stay vigilant.Dozens of staff, children and family members linked to Acorn nursery in Westcroft have tested for the deadly bug Read more on this here:Northern Ireland relaxes two metre ruleSocial distancing in Northern Ireland is to be reduced from two metres to one metre, First Minister Arlene Foster has confirmed. She said: #xCA minimum one-metre distance between iniduals can be considered acceptable in circumstances where appropriate mitigations are made.#xD She said the relaxations had been made through the efforts of people to drive down the rate of infection. #xCNorthern Ireland is opening up again, however there is an onus on all of us not to ease the fight and vigilance against Covid-.#xDFirst Minister Arlene Foster has confirmed a one metre distance would be acceptable :Coronavirus outbreak at Asda meat supplier infects  staffA coronavirus outbreak at an Asda meat factory which supplies bacon rashers has been confirmed as  staff test positive for the virus.Huddersfield MP Barry Sheerman has called for an urgent investigation into what is happening into the UK#xs meat processing plants after the latest outbreak, this time at the Kober factory in Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire.The factory supplies supermarket giant Asda with bacon and was forced to shut last Monday after the outbreak was revealed.Kirklees Council confirmed today that a third of the factory#xs staff tested positive for Covid- but that the meat supplier will remain open and operational.The cases are being followed up by the NHS Test and Trace programme and those affected are being advised to self-isolate for seven days.A staff member dons a mask at the Kober Ltd meat factory in Cleckheaton Read more on this story here:Gym chain to reopen despite government lockdown measuresA gym chain has announced plans to reopen its doors next week - despite health facilities being left out of the lockdown easing.Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday that pubs, hotels, restaurants and hairdressers can reopen from July , as long as social distancing is in place.But gyms, spas, beauty salons and swimming pools were not given the green light to start readmitting the public.However, Gymbox today said bosses are looking at letting its members visit the premises due to the #xClack of clarity from the Government#xD.The gym revealed the industry was led to believe they could welcome back customers on July  - at the same time as the hospitality sector - but are yet to be given an explanation as to why they cannot reopen, the firm said.Senior staff at Gymbox are also looking at partnerships with pubs not planning to reopen to install gym equipment in their boozers so members can hit the #xCbar-bell#xD in order to get around reopening restrictions.Marc Diaper, CEO at Gymbox, said it was #xCoutrageous#xD that pubs were opening before gyms #xCgiven the huge health benefits exercise#xD.Gymbox today said bosses are looking at letting its members visit the premises due to the “lack of clarity from the Government” - stock image:WHO says Covid- getting worse globallyThe COVID- pandemic is subsiding in Europe, but getting worse globally with the number of infections expected to reach  million next week and the number of deaths ,, the head of the World Health Organisation Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said.Speaking via video-conference with members of the European Parliament#xs health committee, Tedros said that once the pandemic was over, the world should notto its previous state, but build a #xCnew normal#xD that would be fairer, greener and help prevent climate change. testing facility in the car park of Chessington World of Adventures, as the spread of the coronavirus diseasecontinues, Chessington, Britain, March , . REUTERS Peter Nicholls" content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _THP_CHP_AI_AJPG.jpg"Medical staff at an NHS drive through coronavirus diseasetesting facility in the car park of Chessington World of Adventures:Walk in centres for testing to be set up for people without cars -  months after lockdown startedWalk-in centres for Covid- testing are to be set up to make it easier for people without cars to get tested for the virus. Six centres are being trialled in Newcastle, Rochdale, Leeds, Brent, Newham and Slough, with the latter described as a hybrid drive and walk through. The exact location of the centres has not been confirmed by officials but one is understood to be on a basketball court, and there have been reports they will spring up in empty shops and car parks. A source at the Department of Health and Social Caresaid officials were working on #xCwalk through testing sites in England for people without cars#xD. The source said that previously the push was to have testing sites out of the way so there were not #xChuge#xD numbers of potentially infected people travelling into the centre of towns. But they added that now incidence is lower, they can look at ways to safely provide testing #xCin the heart of communities#xD, in a way that is more easy and accessible to people. Downing Street said #xCthe right guidance and advice#xD would ensure the safety of walk-in coronavirus testing centres. The Prime Minister#xs official spokesman said: #xCWe have already been setting up mobile testing units to serve communities where needed. #xCWe want to ensure testing is available in places that are accessible and work for the public across the country.#xD :Decline in coronavirus cases has levelled off, ONS figures showThe decline in the number of people in England estimated to have Covid- has levelled off, new figures from the Office for National Statisticssuggest. The ONS said its estimates suggested the percentage testing positive has #xCclearly decreased over time#xD since the first measurement on April  and that #xCthis downward trend has now flattened#xD. An average of , people in private households had coronavirus at any given time between June  and June , according to new ONS estimates. This was the equivalent of .% of the population, or around one in , iniduals. The ONS, which publishes data on how many people at any one time are infected with Covid- based on swab results from households across the country, said: #xCModelling of the trend over time suggests that the decline in the number of people in England testing positive has levelled off in recent weeks. #xCNew modelling of the incidence rate trend over time suggests that incidence appears to have decreased between mid-May and early June, but has also since levelled off.#xD The figures look at community infections and do not include people staying in hospitals, care homes or other institutional settings. The ONS figures also suggest that between June  and June  there were an estimated four new Covid- infections for every , iniduals per week in private households in England - the equivalent of an estimated , new cases per week. This is higher than the estimate of , new cases per week for the period May  to June , but below the , per week estimated for May  to May . The ONS said that despite the latest figures suggesting the proportion of people with Covid- is slightly higher than in previous weeks , the uncertainty surrounding these estimates means #xCwe do not at this point have evidence that the current trend is anything other than flat#xD. The ONS added that, because of this uncertainty, #xCthe actual number of iniduals testing positive in the period June  to June  could be higher or lower than in the two previous periods#xD.:KEY EVENTBournemouth beach major incident declared as heatwave crowds branded appallingA major incident has been declared in Bournemouth after thousands of people packed the beach on the hottest day of the year.Thousands gathered on the beach as temperatures soared to C, with officials describing the scenes as #xCappalling#xD.Bournemouth Council Leader Vikki Slade said: #xCWe are absolutely appalled at the scenes witnessed on our beaches, particularly at Bournemouth and Sandbanks, in the last - hours. #xCThe irresponsible behaviour and actions of so many people is just shocking and our services are stretched to the absolute hilt trying to keep everyone safe. We have had no choice now but to declare a major incident and initiate an emergency response.#xDThe scenes comes just days after Prime Minister eased more lockdown measures, which will see pubs, bars and restaurants open from July .Click here for the full story.A major incident has been declared at Bournemouth beach:UK coronavirus death toll rises by  as daily cases creep back over ,The UK coronavirus death toll has risen by  as the number of daily cases have gone back above ,.The official death toll across all settings is now at , in the latest figures from the Department of Health today. This includes hospitals, care homes and the community.Including deaths from suspected cases of the disease, Britain#xs toll is over ,.There has been a further , new cases of coronavirus reported in the last  hours.Click here for the full story. :UK coronavirus hospital deaths up by  in lowest Thursday rise in lockdownThe UK#xs coronavirus hospital death toll has increased by  - the lowest rise on a Thursday in lockdown.England reported  new deaths, Wales had six, Scotland recorded two and Northern Ireland had zero amid calls for Boris Johnson and his ministers to prepare for a second wave of Covid- this winter. The daily increase of  is the lowest rise on a Thursday since  deaths were confirmed on March , five days before the UK went into lockdown.Read the full story here :Government says R rate still below The rate of spread of the coronavirus infection across the UK - the growth rate - remains at minus % to minus % per day. While the reproduction number, referred to as R, remains at . to .. The figures are unchanged from when they were published by the Government Office for Science and the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies on Friday.Earlier today, a spokesperson for the Prime Minister refused to saychanges to the lockdown would increase the R rate.:Rees-Mogg says pub-goers should enjoy a yard of alePub-goers should #xCgo back to drinking a yard of ale#xD to celebrate the reopening of pubs while adhering to revised social distancing guidance, Jacob Rees-Mogg said. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday that businesses, including pubs, could reopen on July  subject to the latest social distancing requirements being observed. The two-metre social distance rule will be reduced to #xCone-metre plus#xD which works out at just over a yard.Tory MP Brendan Clarke-Smithasked what could be done to support the reopening of pubs.During business questions, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: #xCI think there#xs a very easy answer in pubs and that is people should go back to drinking a yard of ale. #xCBecausethey drink a yard of ale they will maintain social distancing while enjoying an extra large drink to celebrate the fact that they are back in the pub.#xDJacob Rees Mogg :Scotland death toll climbs by twoA total of , patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by two from , on Wednesday, Nicola Sturgeon said.Speaking at the Scottish Government#xs virtual coronavirus briefing, the First Minister said , people have tested positive for the virus in Scotland, up by five from , the previous day.This marks the second day in a row when new cases have been in single figures, the first time this has happened since March , pre-lockdown.There are  people in hospital with confirmed or suspected Covid-, a drop of .Of these patients,  were in intensive care, a fall of five.:Track and Trace reach , people in first three weeksDuring the first three weeks of Test and Trace, , people who had been identied as recent close contacts of people who had tested positive for Covid- were reached through the tracing system. This was % out of a total of , identied contacts. The remaining ,were identied as close contacts, but were not reached. Some of these people could not be reached because no communication details had been provided for them. :KEY EVENTEurope has increase in coronavirus cases for the first time in monthsEurope has reported an increase in coronavirus cases for the first time in months, according to the World Health Organisation .Hans Kluge, the regional director of WHO in Europe, said that there are still , new cases and  deaths every day.Some countries are experiencing cluster outbreaks after many managed to slow the spread of the virus and begin emerging from restrictive lockdowns.He said: #xCIn several countries across Europe, this risk has now become a reality #x  countries have seen increases in new cumulative cases over the past two weeks.#xCIn  of these countries, accelerated transmission has led to very signicant resurgence thatleft unchecked will push health systems to the brink once again in Europe.#xDRead more here.Deaths are declining in Europe but there are grim warnings of a second spike :Infectious diseases expert warns coronavirus cases could resurge as travel restrictions relaxInfectious diseases specialist Professor Paddy Mallon has told a coronavirus committee in Ireland he believes it is inevitable that the country will experience a resurgence of cases as it relaxes restrictions and permits more travel. He said: #xCWhat countries that Ireland is in the position of around the world have done with resurgence of cases - the majority of the resurgence is occurring because new infections are being introduced into the country either through people travelling into the country or through the movement of goods. #xCThe importance of containing infections at borders become higher as levels of community transmission drop off. So from the policy maker perspective,you want to maintain community transmission at a level that is minimum, it is important you have robust screening methods at the point of entry into the country. #xCWhat they are is open for debate - you could screen everyone or judge your screening and restrictions on the epidemiological of the outbreak of the country the person is coming from. Someone coming from New Zealand compared to someone from Texas - the risk assessments would be very dferent.#xD:EasyJet will restart more UK and international flights from July EasyJet has announced plans to restart more flights on July .The airline will restart the domestic and international flights from  airports across the UK.Holidaymakers will be able to fly abroad from London Gatwick, London Luton, Bristol, Manchester, Newcastle, Edinburgh and Belfast to a number of countries including France, Italy and Spain.Read more here.The airline plans to resume more flights within weeks :Fire chiefs rubbish claims hand sanitiser left in hot cars is a fire riskHand sanitiser left in a hot car is not a fire risk, fire chiefs have said.The National Fire Chiefs council said there had been no cases of such fires in the UK.Debunking the myth: Hand sanitiser kept in cars DO NOT pose a fire risk.Following widespread news coverage claiming that hand sanitiser kept in vehicles can pose a fire risk, we refute this - and confirm there have been no cases of such fires in the UK.https:t.co yAmatLQWmdash National Fire Chiefs CouncilJune ,  After concerns were raised about whether it was safe to store hand sanitiser in hot cars during the soaring heat in the UK this week, Good Morning Britain#xs Dr Hilary Jones addressed the claims on telly this morning too.Read more here.:Martin Lewis issues urgent travel insurance warning to Brits going on holidayPersonal finance guru Martin Lewis has released a valuable guide for anyone who is hoping to travel abroad this summer which includes vital travel insurance advice.Currently the Foreign Office currently advises against all non-essential travel, but holidays abroad are expected to reopen imminently.The government is in talks with countries including Spain on air bridges, where Brit travellers could avoid having to quarantine on either sidethey can strike up an agreement amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.Read more on his tipsyou#xre planning holidays here.Spain is expected to be added to the list of safe countries :Fights break out at Brixton street party inuring  police as they warn against lockdown gatheringsFteen police officers have been injured as they tried to break up a street party in Brixton, South London.The street party turned into a riot last night as violent disturbances prompted emergency calls.The Met Police said they had received complaints from local residents complaining about a large gathering and disturbance.The force said: #xCThese gatherings are unlawful, as well as posing a risk to public health and against coronavirus restrictions.#xCThe violence shown towards officers is totally unacceptable and we will not tolerate it in any form.#xD Read more here.Police trying to break up the gathering in Brixton last night :Gulf coronavirus infections surpass ,The number of coronavirus cases in the six Gulf Arab states has doubled in a month to over ,.As of Wednesday evening, the tally in the energy producing region stood at , infections, with , deaths. It passed the , mark on May . Regional business hub the United Arab Emirates announced late on Wednesday the lting of a nightly curfew in place since mid-March as the daily number of infections fell from a peak of some  in late May to average between - in recent weeks.Neighbouring Saudi Arabia, which has the highest regional count at more than , infections and over , deaths, fully removed its three-month curfew on Sunday.Kuwait is the only Gulf state that still has a partial curfew. Qatar, Oman and Bahrain did not impose curfews as part of measures to combat the disease.Cases are rising in Dubai :Greek tourism minster wants British tourists to Greek tourism minister Haris Theoharis said the country wanted British tourists towhen it opens to European holidaymakers on July . #xCThe final decision, from the UK and our point of view, will be in place in the next few days and I#xm hoping the announcement will be positive from both sides,#xD said Mr Theoharis, who indicated conversations with the UK Government over so-called #xCair bridges#xD were going well. He told BBC Radio #xs Today programme there was no need for those ing to the UK from Greece to be quarantined. #xCThe point is that Greece is a safe country - we have proven that during this crisis and we will continue proving this in the exit stages of the health situation,#xD said the Greek minister. #xCWe feel that the risk of someone contracting the disease in Greece is much lower than most of the countries in Europe and indeed the rest of the world.#xD Put to him that there was no point in the quarantine from those ing from Greece, Mr Theoharis replied: #xCCorrect.#xD:Coronavirus guidance for cinemas ahead of reopenings next monthExtra cleaning, staggered film start times and a focus on online booking are some of the measures cinemas will be encouraged to implement as they re-open their doors.Cinemas in England will be able to welcome back customers from July , and July  in Scotland. Guidance includes measures to ensure social distancing throughout cinemas, with an emphasis on auditoriums and enhanced cleaning and hygiene procedures. Customers will be asked to use contactless payment where possible, the guidance said, while online booking will also be encouraged. Plastic screens will be installed at #xCkey contact points#xD and film schedules will be adjusted to allow cleaning of auditoriums between screenings and to avoid crowding in corridors. Phil Clapp, chief executive of the UK Cinema Associationsaid: #xCToday#xs launch represents an important next step in our efforts to once again bring the big screen experience to the cinema-going public. #xCWe know from recent surveys that a large proportion of our audience can#xt wait to come back, but they understandably want to know the steps that cinemas will be taking to ensure their continued welfare.#xD Showcase Cinemas said it will reopen on July  while Cineworld and Picturehouse cinemas have announced plans to reopen on July .A woman wearing a face mask walks past a closed branch of cinema chain Curzon :Coronavirus lockdown changes: What is still illegal after July  in EnglandHuge changes to the coronavirus lockdown in England are coming on Saturday  July.Pubs, restaurants, hotels and hairdressers will be allowed to reopen and people will be able to gather in slightly larger groups.For the first time, two households of any size will be able to gather inside - with social distancing.Two households also be able to gather outside, on top of the rule that says up to six people from dferent households can meet.The two-metre rule will be cut to one metre plus mitigations like face coverings, where two metres can#xt be maintained.But there#xs another more fundamental change too. For the first time since March, many of the laws that govern people#xs behaviour will be wound down.Read the full story here:KEY EVENTFive schools in hotspot UK city closed after coronavirus outbreaksFive schools in a coronavirus #xChotspot#xD UK city have been forced to close after staff members tested positive for the killer virus.Deep cleans are underway at the schools in Leicester, the city where it was last week revealed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock a localised outbreak of Covid- had taken hold.However, the city council#xs strategic director of education and social care Martin Samuels moved to reassure parents and the wider public about the situation.Read the full story here.:KEY EVENTRoyal Mail to axe , jobs in bid to cut costsRoyal Mail is set to make , workers redundant in a huge #xAmillion restructuring move that#xs been accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic.The UK#xs postal service said it needs to take #xCimmediate action#xD after profits before tax plunged % to #xAmillion in the year to March.A further #xAmillion is set to be axed in spending until  to address the impact of coronavirus, which saw Saturday post suspended temporarily to due to increased staff absences.Interim CEO Keith Williams, who took the reins after the departure of Rico Back in May, said Royal Mail has been too slow to pivot its business to prioritise parcels over letters.#xCIn recent years, our UK business has not adapted quickly enough to the changes in our marketplace of more parcels and fewer letters. COVID- has accelerated those trends, presenting additional challenges,#xD he said.Read the full story here.:Europes cities gear up for post-lockdown tourismAnyone visiting the Efel Tower in Paris when it reopens on Thursday will have to take the stairs - all  of them - because France#xs iconic monument is keeping the lts shut. After months of lockdown many Europeans are dreaming of a summer holiday, but vacations will look a bit dferent this year - breakfast buffets, guided tours and club nights may well be out masks and temperature checks are definitely in.Tourist attractions from Rome#xs Colosseum to Amsterdam#xs Hermitage museum have introduced a slew of measures to minimise the risk of a new outbreak of coronavirus which has killed about , people in western Europe. In Italy, the Leaning Tower of Pisa and Florence#xs striking cathedral are turning to technology to enforce social distancing, providing visitors with electronic devices which vibratethey get too close to one another. In Barcelona, the authorities are launching an app to help tourists in Spain#xs second city plan their itineraries and avoid congestion and queues.Tourists wearing face masks pose for a photograph near the tower of Pisa :Hundreds line the streets as Dunkirk hero turns  after Covid- cancels partyHundreds of people lined the streets as a Dunkirk hero turned , after his party was cancelled due to Covid-.Veteran Eric Taylor was treated to a military parade and fly-past, and a brass band as he enjoyed the festivities from his garden.Eric, of Helston, Cornwall, said: #xCI#xm so pleased to reach this age and still able to enjoy what I#xve received, with everybody helping to make a tremendous day on my th birthday.#xDHundreds of people lined the streets as a Dunkirk hero turned , after his party was cancelled due to Covid-.Veteran Eric Taylor was treated to a military parade and fly-past, and a brass band as he enjoyed the festivities from his garden.Eric, of Helston, Cornwall, said: #xCI#xm so pleased to reach this age and still able to enjoy what I#xve received, with everybody helping to make a tremendous day on my th birthday.#xDRead the full story here. In his role of heir to the throne, the Queenaposs oldest son is entitled to the surplus generated by the Duchyaposs vast portfolio of land, buildings and financial investments.He uses the cash to fund his charity work and to support the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle.In the - financial year, his annual private income from the hereditary estate rose by £, - .% - from £,, in - to £,,. However itaposs likely that next year will see a huge drop in profits due to the coronavirus pandemic, the secretary and keeper Alastair Martin has warned. He said: The lockdown resulting from Covid- was only in place for one week of the financial year that this report covers. There is therefore very limited financial impact on these results. As to -, it is too early in the new financial year to be able to say with any confidence what the impact on our financial performance will be, but, despite having a particularly well-ersied asset base, we fully expect the revenue surplus to be down by a signicant amount, in large part due to our trading enterprises being closed. He added: We have not availed ourselves of the ious government pandemic support schemes but have continued to pay all staff.  Republic, which campaigns for an elected head of state, called for the Government to take control of the estate and stop the prince keeping the surplus.Graham Smith, chief executive of the pressure group, said: There is simply no justication for this ludicrous amount of money to be thrown at Charles when public services are stretched and local communities are impacted by the coronavirus.Itaposs time the Duchy was rolled back into the Crown Estate and its income served the British people, not one prince. The Duchy said that the volatility and uncertainty posed no short or long term financial threat to the asset values of its properties. The private landed estate was created in  by Edward III to support his son and heir Prince Edward, known as the Black Prince, and all his subsequent heirs. It extends across  counties in England and Wales and includes the Oval cricket ground and , acres of Dartmoor. Mr Martin said the coronavirus crisis had caused signicant personal and financial disruption for many Duchy tenants, particularly in the Isles of Scilly and Cornwall, where the economy is reliant on tourism and hospitality. He highlighted the uncertain future and pledged to work with the tenants to help them in the wake of the pandemic. It is unclear how the coming year will unfold. During this dficult and anxious time for the Duchy family, we will continue to maintain close links with all our tenants and work with them to re-establish, where possible, their livelihoods, he said. Rent deferrals have been agreed with many tenants, he added. The report also highlighted legislative hiatus over the UKaposs departure from the EU as having an impact. Uncertainty arising from this hiatus makes planning and investment decisions more complex. This is an area of deep concern for our agricultural tenants in particular, it said. story: NewsUK weather forecast: Storms to grind heatwave to halt as mercury plunges C in two daysAfter temperatures in London reach C today, Saturday will see highs of just C in the capital, as forecasters predict heavy rain and lower temperatures this weekendShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  JUN NewsHeavy rain and plummeting temperatures are forecast this weekend " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
